Award.AwardTitle: Student Participation at the 15th Advanced Accelerator Concepts Workshop, held in Austin,TX June 10-15, 2012.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Particle accelerators have become the largest and most expensive of scientific instruments. Thirty years ago, a biennial Advanced Accelerator Concepts (AAC) Workshop series began as an effort to bring together U. S. researchers and selected foreign representatives from diverse technical backgrounds to explore new ideas for making accelerators leaner and meaner. The PI is now organizing the 15th AAC workshop, to be held June 10-15, 2012 in Austin, Texas. Student participation is becoming an increasingly important component of these meetings. Recent AAC workshops have featured a student poster session, several best poster student prizes, oral presentations by the winners in the closing plenary session, and partial student scholarships. The upcoming 15th AAC Workshop will continue these features, while increasing student participation from 50 to approximately 60, and for the first time providing a series of tutorials aimed specifically at student attendees.

The primary objective of the use of the funds is to reduce the cost of U. S. student attendance at the 15th AAC Workshop in Austin, Texas. Funds will be distributed as 20 NSF AAC student scholarships of $500 each to qualified student participants from U.S. institutions. Students will be invited to apply for scholarships through an advertisement on the AAC workshop web site and by email. Recipients will be selected by a multi-institutional committee of senior workshop participants based on scientific merit of the students application, letters of recommendation, and institutional balance. Applications from minorities, women, and persons with disabilities will be particularly encouraged.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided 20 scholarships of $500 each to graduate students from U.S. institutions to attend the 15th Advanced Accelerator Concepts workshop (AAC 2012) held in Austin, Texas, June 10-15, 2012.   On-line applications for the scholarships were received from 35 students at 14 different institutions, from which recipients were chosen based on excellence of their research, a letter of recommendation from their supervisors, and institutional, geographic and gender diversity.  The NSF scholarship program helped to bring about the largest student participation (70) in the 30-year history of the AAC workshop series.  Each student awardee presented his/her research in poster format, and participated in a week-long program of plenary and working group presentations and social activities with senior accelerator scientists.  The Working Group Leaders of AAC 2012 awarded AAC Student Poster Prizes to six oustanding student posters, which the winning students presented orally in a special plenary session on the final day of the workshop.  Students also attended a series of three introductory tutorials by renowned experts in advanced accelerator science that were aimed at, and restricted to, students.

The biennial AAC workshops are the principal U.S. forum for discussion of forefront research on new approaches to particle acceleration.  AAC 2012 brought together over 250 researchers from around the world who reported recent advances in areas including laser-driven plasma acceleration of electrons, protons and ions, new accelerator structures based on dielectrics and metamaterials, new laser technology for advanced accelerators, new accelerator diagnostics and computational methods, accelerator-based radiation sources, and muon colliders.

Since the first cyclotrons, betatrons and linear accelerators were developed in the 1930s, particle accelerators have evolved into the 21st century's most powerful scientific instruments.  They are used to probe nature's deepest sub-atomic secrets, to produce bright x-rays that reveal the structure of molecules essential to life, and to irradiate cancerous tumors.  However, they have also become the largest and most expensive of scientific instruments. The AAC workshop series was launched in 1982 to bring together researchers from diverse technical backgrounds to explore new ideas for making accelerators "leaner and meaner".  An opening plenary presentation by AAC pioneer Chandrashekhar Joshi of UCLA reviewed 30 years of progress under the AAC umbrella.  Highlights reported at AAC 2012 included nearly mono-energetic acceleration of electrons to 2 giga-electron-volts (GeV) in a laser-driven plasma cell only a few inches long, and nearly mono-energetic acceleration of protons to tens of millions of electron-volts (MeV) in a laser-driven gas jet and in laser-driven nano-foils. These extremely compact sources of energetic particles have potential applications, respectively, in production of bright x-rays for studying the structure of bio-molecules and in treatment of deep cancers.  The strong participation of students in AAC will help ensure that these dreams become a reality in coming years.
